awd_titl_txt: Diet and Feeding Ecology of the Primate Chiropotes Santanas
awd_abstract_narration: This project will test the hypothesis that the dentition of the                 black saki monkey reduces resistant dietary items (hard fruits,                 seeds, nuts) that are critical to the animal's diet; and that                   these hard food items are opened with canine teeth specialized                  for applying high pressure during puncturing and chewed with                    flat, thick enameled molars capable of applying high pressure                   during crushing, and that these foods are not accessable to                     similar primates with different tooth formations.  These                        hypotheses will be tested by observation of feeding and ranging                 behavior of black saki and similar spider monkeys in the                        forests of Northern South America, and by analysis of                           availability, use, and the physical and chemical properties of                  the food items eaten.  The project will use a new method of                     measuring the resistance to puncturing and crushing of the                      foods.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK
